comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...

comment._content: John Maiden, one of the turn of the century directors of the gardens, was a big believer in providing drinking water. Mainly as a temperance strategy.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...

comment._content: The date palm (see note) should provide a date!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More seriously though, The City of Sydney website has a page about drinking fountains, and the pdf file at the section "The Fountains of Sydney, 1913" has another different image of this fountain in the Palm Grove at the Botanic Gardens from an Evening News article (bottom left image). www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/waterexhibition/drinkingplace... My guess is this image is about 1900. Maybe the fountain is still there and has a plaque with details attached?

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: also, according to www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/welcome_to_bgt/royal_botanic_garden... in 1912 many of the fountains in the park were converted to bubblers. perhaps this might suggest a narrower date for the image?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks for all the great comments about the Cupid statue....when posting the image we never imagined that a water bubbler would be the vital clue to dating the image.  Sounds like a good excuse to visit to the Botanic Gardens to see if the statue is still standing......

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: I seem to think it's not still there but I might check it out next weekend when I'm up there. The Botanic Gardens Trust might also hold some valuable information that will help date and find further info!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: BobMeade - I found a copy of The Wishing Tree today. When I get a moment I'll post the relevant entry, in the meantime: Removed c.1917.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
from The Wishing Tree (pub. details previously cited) pp. 124-125
_____

Drinking Fountains

Last century drinking fountains were literally that - monumental fountains with a series of small spouts, often equipped with drinking cups on chains. The position of drinking fountains in the Gardens were marked on Maiden's 1903 map as small squares with a dot in them. J. H. Maiden, in his evidence the the Royal Commission on the improvements of Sydney, 1909, said: 'Every street in Sydney should have its drinking-fountain. It should be at least as easy to obtain a drink of pure water as a glass of milk or beer. Sydney is a sub-tropical city, and sometimes it is warm and sometimes it is dusty ... Sydney should be a city of fountains.' [source: David Churches, The Cultural Significance of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney, 1990, p. 791.]

In Maiden's time there were many drinking fountains in the Gardens:

(a) Palm Grove
Source: -
Date/Place: Located at entrance to Palm Grove, marked as K on Maiden's map of 1903
Removed: c. 1917
Additional Information: The ornate marble drinking fountain in the Palm Grove (site identified by old photographs) was surmounted by small marble(?) statue of girl (angel?) on a stand supported by four columns. Maiden complained that: 'certain mischievous boys and other people delight in wrenching off the cups, damaging the spouts and injuring the fountains in various ways'. By 1914: 'The old taps and enamel mugs, which had been in use for drinking purposes fro varying periods ... [were replaced with] ... bubbling fountains ... which have been in use in the Botanical Gardens and Outer Domain for some years. They are more sanitary, and are appreciated by the public.' [source: BG/AR, 1915, p. 40.] The existing sandstone bubblers in the Gardens probably come from this era. The new bubblers, on the path from the Tropical Centre to the Palm Grove and at the top of the Palace Garden Steps, were made in the same style.
_____

There is an associated photo with the entry of the fountain dated 1887, from the RBG Library.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Here is a similar photograph by Henry King from the Powerhouse Museum's Tyrrell collection: www.powerhousemuseum.com/imageservices/index.php/2010/02/... And here in the zoomable collection database: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=30967 Zooming in makes it clear that the base, columns and cupola of the drinking fountain are of marble, although the bottommost plinth appears to not be of marble. The woman in the Henry King photograph is holding a mug which she is filling with liquid from a fountain spout.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the Henry King links. There's some great detail there. I love the kids standing around and the 'snapshot' feel. I should have mentioned the photograph in The Wishing Tree shows a man filing a mug.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
What a happy coincidence to find another image of the same fountain!  It has been here on Flickr for a couple of years -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363503468/].

Judging by the palm / cycad on the left of the fountain in both images, this photo would seem to be a couple of years later than Henry King's, where the plant is looking sad and in need of a drink, unlike here.  The PhM date King's at c.1895, so maybe this is c.1897?

As I said before, the palm will provide a date!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Edwin Wilson sent me this message:

"The photo is of the old drinking fountain in the Palm Grove with an enamel mug attached (like the chained pens in old banks). See The Wishing Tree, p. 123. Am retired now and don’t come into the Gardens very often. Regards Edwin Wilson"

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thank you all for all the detailed research you have put into the history of the statue/drinking fountain image.  If only we could go back in time and have a drink of water from the grand old fountain.....

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ State Records NSW - I don't think we're done just yet! And you would not drink there if you had read this letter in the Sydney Morning Herald on 4 November 1886 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13619318?searchTerm=foun... An odd thing - the base / plinth is a different shape and height in each photo. The Henry King photo has the corners clipped (to match the fountain shape), and made of flagstones. This picture has what looks like a poured concrete base a few centimetres higher with square corners. I wonder why they repaired it so soon (and badly)? This SMH article (18/12/1889) may refer to the wrong fountain - it talks about a bronze statue of a water nymph and "jets", unveiled on Tuesday 17 December 1889 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13753716?searchTerm=foun... . Opinions?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Those articles are a great find beachcomberaustralia. The fountain the 1889 article refers to is the art nouveau Lewis Wolfe Levy Fountain And yes the base is different isn't it? Also notice the surrounding landscaping of the palm grove beds is quite different. Was the fountain moved I wonder, which would explain the new base, or was the design of the palm grove changed, which I guess is more likely?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks pellethepoet. Sorry for the false alarm. Maybe this is the right statue, a poem in the SMH 25/3/1933. It is not clear if it is a favourite old poem, or the fountain was still there in 1933 (I thought it was removed in 1917) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16957779
